description:
Drosophila sulfurigaster albostrigata is a species of fruit fly belonging to the Drosophila genus. It is a subspecies of Drosophila sulfurigaster, which is a member of the Drosophila melanogaster species group.

Drosophila sulfurigaster albostrigata is characterized by its small size, with a body length typically ranging from 2.5 to 3.5 millimeters. The flies have a yellowish-brown coloration with distinct white stripes on their abdomen, which is the primary distinguishing feature of this subspecies.

This species is primarily found in Southeast Asia, including regions such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and parts of Thailand. It is commonly associated with rotting fruits and other decaying organic matter, where it feeds and lays its eggs.

Drosophila sulfurigaster albostrigata, like other Drosophila species, has a short life cycle, with the complete development from egg to adult taking approximately 10-12 days under optimal conditions. It is a valuable model organism in various areas of biological research, particularly in the fields of genetics, developmental biology, and evolutionary studies.
